Here is how the structure of the ancient Egyptian system of government works. To start off, at the top were the gods, like Ra, Osiris, and Isis stated on paragraph 1. Pharaoh's were the next and egyptians believed Pharaoh's were gods but in human forms and they had absolute power over their subjects which is stated on paragraph 2. The pharaoh directed an army  in case of a foreign threat or an internal conflict stated on paragraph 3. All laws were enacted at the discretion of the pharaoh. Each farmer paid taxes in the form of grains, which were stored in the pharaoh's warehouses. This grain was used to feed the people in the event of a famine stated on paragraph 3.  The pharaoh appointed a cheif minister called a vizier as a supervisor. The vizier ensured that taxes were collected stated on paragraph 4. Working with the vizier were scribes who kept government records. These high-level employess had mastered a rare skill in ancient Egypt, they could read and write stated on paragraph 5. Below pharaoh's were nobles and priests. Only nobles could hold government posts, which in these positions they profited from tributes, paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods stated on paragraph 6. Soliders fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. During long periods of peace, soilders also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved in building structures like pyramids and palaces stated on paragraph 8. Skilled workers like physicians and craftsmen/women made up the middle class. Craftsmen made and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus, products, tools, and other useful things stated on paragraph 9.  There were people that needed to buy goods from artisians and traders. These were the merchants and storekeepers who sold these goods to the public stated on paragraph 10.  At the bottom of the social structure were the slaves and farmers. Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. Being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles stated on paragraph 11. Farmers tended the fields. raised animals, kept canals, and reservoirs in good order, worked in stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. Farmers paid taxes that could do as much as 60% of their yearly harvest stated on paragraph 12. Social mobility was not impossible. A small number of peasants and farmers moved up the economic ladder. Families saved money to send their sons to village schools to learn trades.  These schools were run by priests or by artisans. Boys who learned to read and write could become scribes, then go on a gain employment in the government stated on paragraph 13.  That is how the system of Ancient Egypt worked.

The structure of the ancient Egyptian system of goverment has five different social classes.  The first class, and the highest of them, is the pharoh.  The pharoh is the leader of the area and was beleived to be human gods, the pharoh had responsibilities like protecting Egypt.  In the third paragraph, it states " Their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form. "  This qoute explains the Egyptians beliefs and why the pharohs were leaders.   The second highest, were the powerful nobles and priets.  The nobles held the goverment posts, while the priests were responsible with pleasing the gods.  In the sixth paragraph, it sites that "Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods."  This qoute explains what the preists and nobles did and it shows their importance.  Physicians and craftsmen/women were in the middle class.  They made and sold jewerly, pottery, papyrus products and some other useful and wanted objects.  In paragraph nine it states that "Craftsmen made and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus products, tools, and other useful things."  This helps explain their job which is why they were in  the middle class.  Below the middle class is the merchants and storekeepers.  Their job was selling goods the the public.  In the tenth paragraph, the author states that "These were the merchants and storekeepers who sold these goods to the public."  This qoute helps explain what their jobs were,  In the bottom class,  they had the slaves and farmers.  The slaves jobs were to follow orders, work on building projects.  In the eleventh paragraph, it states that " Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. In addition to being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles."  This qoute helps explain my answer because it states what work slaves had to do.  The farmers job was to tend fields, raise animals, kept canals, and more.  In the twelveth paragraph, the author mentions that "Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in good order, worked in the stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. Farmers paid taxes that could amount to as much as 60% of their yearly harvest\u2014that\u2019s a lot of hay!"  This qoute helps explain my answer because it explains what the farmers do for a living.  The better the job you had for a living, the higher you would be on the System of Goverment pyramid.  All in all, the structure of  the ancient Egyptian system of goverment heavily depends on what your job is.

Ancient Egypt's system of government is different from what ours is like today. At the top of Egypt's system of government, is the gods. The gods were at the top because the Egyptians believed that the gods controlled the world. In the text it states, "Egyptians believed that the gods controlled the universe." The quote from the text shows that the gods were in charge. Next, on the system of government was the pharoahs. The pharaohs had lots of power. The text says, "Their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form. They had absolute power over their subjects." The quote shows that the pharoahs had a lot of controll. The pharaohs also directed the army in case of a conflict. According to the text, "The pharaoh directed the army in case of a foreign threat or an internal conflict. " The quote shows they had power. Then, below the pharoahs were the nobles and the priests.  The nobles held government posts, and the priests were responsible for pleasing gods. In the text it says, "Right below the pharaoh in status were powerful nobles and priests. Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods." Next, were the vizers. The vizers ensured that all taxes were collected. The text says, "The pharaoh appointed a chief minister called a vizier as a supervisor. The vizier ensured that taxes were collected." The quote above shows that the vizers had to make sure everyone paid their taxes.Also, the scribes worked with the vizers. The scribes kept government records. They could also read and write. In the text is says, "Working with the vizier were scribes who kept government records. These high-level employees had mastered a rare skill in ancient Egypt \u2014 they could read and write." This shows that they had an important skill and job. At the bottom of the structure were slaves and farmers. Slaves were forced to work on building projects. The slaves had to do hard labor. The farmers worked on the fields, raised aimals, kept canals and reservoirs in good shape, and much more. To prove that, the text states, "Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. In addition to being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles. Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in good order, worked in the stone quarries, and built the royal monuments." Farmers also paid taxes that could take away as much as 60% of their yearly-harvest.  As one can see, all people in ancient Egypt had  job, and that ancient Egypt's social structure is different from today. One can also see how different levels of social classes had different power. Egypt's system of government played a important role in ancient Egypt.

The text says that the social structure works similar to that of a pyramid.  At the top, of course, is the gods. Because, I mean, THEY'RE GODS. Underneath them is the Pharohs. This is due to the fact that people believe that the Pharohs were the human versions of the gods. The Pharohs held the most responsiblility and were the most powerful. They were also buried within stone pyramids. Beneath the Pharohs lies the Nobles, who essentially were the government. To quote from the text, they "profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh." Oh yeah, and the Preists (also up here with the Nobles) had the job of making sure that the gods were happy, and didn't hypothetically cause the destruction of humanity,  but THAT DOESN'T MATTER. Anyways, next is the middle class. the middle class, of course, was in the middle.  It contained craftsmen(men refering to both men and women, plus the possible addition of nonbinary peeps if the term hypothetically existed at the time) and shopkeepers. But what did they make? What did they sell? Well what do YOU think?? Ok, I might understand if you were having trouble figuring out what craftsmen did(which was make things such as jewlery,pottery, and tools by the way),  but shopkeepers??? I think you might be able to find out yourself. OK, MOVING ON, we have soldiers. Who, in most societies, you might expect to be higher than the middle class, but NOPE. THEY'RE AT THE BOTTOM. Well, not at the bottom, but.. Let's just say that in the egyptian society, you're either at the top, or at the bottom. And, despite the existence of the middle class, THERE IS NO INBETWEEN. So, yeah. Soldiers. They uh, fought in wars, of course, and they also supervised the peaseants and farmers...That's all I really know. Sorry. Alright, and now the moment in which you bois n gals n nonbinary pals have all been waiting for...the absolute bottom...the lowest of the lows...drumroll please...SLAVES AND FARMERS, YALL! Aight so slaves were essentially made out of a whole bunch of peeps who were taken captive during war, and such. They were used to work on building projects, and let's be honest, were probably treated like crap. And farmers, on the other hand, were...FARMERS! And they did, uh...Very..Farmer-y things. They..THEY WERE FARMERS. They also helped build royal monuments, and, to quote from the text, "paid taxes that could amount to as much as 60% of their yearly harvest". So, if their yearly harvest were hypothetically around, let's say...$10,000, then they'd be left with...*calculating*...$4,000. So, when it came to taxes, farmers, too, WERE TREATED. LIKE. CRAP. (and I personally dont think that the farmers should be so low because unlike everyone else, they make the food that's KEEPING EVERYONE ELSE A L I V E. that's just how I see it thought.)

The base starts with farmers and slaves. The economical positions rise as they go up. At the very top point of the pyramid are the gods. Here is the order from greatest to least: Egyptian Gods/Pharaohs,  nobles/priests, soldiers, craftmen/traders, and lastly farmers/slaves. The gods are at the highest position in status. They have the right to overpower everyone. Also, since everyone praises them they believe that the gods were responsible of many things as well. Like safety. Sometimes the pharaohs direct the army or create laws. As stated in the text, "They had absolute power over their subjects...The pharaoh directed the army in case of a foreign threat or an internal conflict. All the laws were enacted at the discretion of the pharaoh." Because the pharaohs/gods couldn't do all the duties themselves they have assistants called viziers which are chief ministers. They have the duty of collecting taxes from people like farmers. According to the article, "No single person could manage all these duties without assistance. The pharaoh appointed a chief minister called a vizier as a supervisor. The vizier ensured that taxes were collected." Called a "chain of command" the viziers have assistants as well.  They are called scribes; they are the only ones who can read and write. Now under the whole chain of gods/pharaohs there are the nobles/priests. According to the text, the only people who can develop government posts are the nobles. And priests' duties are to keep the gods satisfied. Like said in the text, "Right below the pharaoh in status were powerful nobles and priests. Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods." Also, the nobles grow very wealthy from recieving all the gifts of the gods from the subjects. Next are the soldiers. The soldiers fight in wars or end "domestic uprisings." Also, they sometimes keep an eye on farmers, peasants, and slaves. As said in the article, "Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. During long periods of peace, soldiers also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved in building such structures as pyramids and palaces." Next comes the middle class which is made up of skilled people life artisans, craftmen/women, and physicians. The craftmen would create jewlery and other products and then sell them to make some money. They were known as the merchants and sorekeepers. "Skilled workers such as physicians and craftsmen/women made up the middle class. Craftsmen made and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus products, tools, and other useful things. Naturally, there were people needed to buy goods from artisans and traders. These were the merchants and storekeepers who sold these goods to the public." And at the bottom/base are the farmers and slaves. The farmers has to raise animals, take care of the fields, conduct some tasks in the stone quarries, construct royal monuments, and are responsible to keep the reservoirs and canals in shape. They also have to pay 60% of their annual harvest towards tax. "Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs  in good order, worked in the stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. Farmers paid taxes that could amount to as much as 60% of their yearly harvest\u2014that\u2019s a lot of hay!"  Although people can't raise their status, young boys can go to school to learn how to read/write and then can become scribes or can apply for employment in the government which would make their status rise. The slaves have to work on developing projects and put extreme effort at the disrection of the nobles or pharaohs. "At the bottom of the social structure were slaves and farmers. Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. In addition to being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles."

There were various ways the factories would use or cover up spoiled meat. This included mixing fresher meat with spoiled meat. " The factories took advantage selling meat under the guise of names like "California Hams" and "Head Cheese".

They would rub it up with soda to get rid of the sour smell. The workers would dose it with borax and glycerin and made over again so people would eat them. The workers also would clean out the hoopers once in a while and had dirt and old nails, rust, and stale water. That would be dumped into the fresh meat. They would preserve it in borax and color it to look brown and would sell it for more because of a sticker they put that said "special".

There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together.

The factory would use multiple unsanitary way to cover up the spoiled meats such as chemicals, mixing them with other meats, or adding color. In the final paragraph Sinclair writes, "...they would call upon their chemisty department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown." In the first paragraph they also write "...whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used ofr anything else, either to can it or else chop it up into sausage." This quote explains that the packers would use the spoiled meat again by just griding it up.

Not only would they mix spoiled meat with good meat but they would use parts of the animals that werent even meat. they would use chemicals to help mask the disgusting smells. They would pump chemicals into a spoiled pig to mask the smell. In the passage it says, "by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them". This meat industry was very currupt.

It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white\u2014it would be dosed with borax and glycerine, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption

The factory would often use soda and other chemicals to cover up meat that had become sour. Many hams that were found spoiled even after this previous practice were injected with another type of pickling agent. The text describes the factory's practice, saying, "...had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor - a process known...as 'giving them thrity per cent' " (Sinclair).  Spoiled meats with bones soon became Number One Grade due to the industry's method of extracting the bone and practice where workers would "insert into the hole a white-hot iron" (Sinclair).

Due to the smell of a poiled meat they had found a way to make it go away. As stated in the text,  "how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell." With the "miracle" of chemicals they now had the complete control to change spoiled meat into something that seemed edible.  The passage states. "also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. " With no regulations the meat industry had no one to stop their chemical experiments on meat sold to the public.

Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose.  Old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white; it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption.

The factory would chop the spoiled meat up and mix it with other meats, pour soda on it, or dose them in chemicals. The chopped and mix meat would be for sausages. The factory would use several different ways to cover up spoiled meat and use it. One such way according to The Jungle was to, "The packers were always originating such schemes\u2014they had what they called \u201cboneless hams,\u201d which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and \u201cCalifornia hams,\u201d which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out." They would cut up the spoiled ham and mix it with several other types of meat to mask the smell of the spoiled meat.

The meatpacking factories had many means of covering up and using spoiled meat. One such way was by pumping the ham with a "much stronger pickle that destroyed the odor." Another way they were able to use spoiled meat was by pulling out the bone, which is where "the bad part generally lay." In this way the rest of the meat was still used. When an entire ham was spoiled, moldy,  and white, is was used for sausage where "no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference." Using these methods, the meatpackers were able to use and distribute meat of terrible quality for consumption.

The factory would cover up spoiled meat by pumping it with "a second and much stronger pickle" to destroy the odor (Paragraph 2). Factories would use spoiled meat that had heavy and coarse skins. They would cook and finely chop the hogs and label them as "head cheese!" (Paragraph 2).  Spoiled meat all the way from Europe would be dosed with borax and glycerin then dumped into the hoppers and made over again so it would be edible (Paragraph 3). No matter how much mold or how many times the meat was rejected factories came up with ways to still save it to make their money.

Various ways the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat would be to douse the meat with borax & glycerin, etc. The text states, "...a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds... Europe sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white -- it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into hoppers".  This explains how disgusting and unsanitary the meat idustry was/is. It also shows how meat industries would do anything to stay in business.

The factory would put chemicals like borax and glycerin onto the old meat and sell it again, or they would cut up the old meat and put it in  with the new maeat so that nobody could tell if the meat was old. And it also covered up the oder of the old meat.  Another way they would cover up the meat, was that they put the spoild meat into barrels and leave the barrels in cellers to rot. From the text. "There were the butt-ends of smoked meat, and the scraps of corned beef, and all the odds and ends of the waste of the plants, that would be dumped into old barrels in the cellar and left there."

When the entire meat was spoiled, they would send it to a deparment. Stating ,".....mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference" (Paragraph 3)This concealed the odor of the spoiled meat; hiding the spoiled meat with other meat to make it seem fine. Another method they used was to inject a ton of pickles into the spoiled meat to remove the odor. From the book, it states, " pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor" (Paragraph 2).  Due to this, they hid the spoiled meat not just in bits, but in plain sight.

Some ways how the factory would cover up spoiled meat would be to mix it with the sausage. According to the text, "There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." (paragraph 3) Another way they covered up the spoiled meat was by putting it inside of hams. The passage states, "The packers were always originating such schemes--they had what they called 'boneless hams,' which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings;" These were only a few ways how they disguised the spoiled meat.

In this article, it states that "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." This quote states that, they would take the smell out of the rotten meat was rubbing it up with soda and then use chemicals to make it look fresh again. This causes a lot of health problems and causes people to get sick, and in worst scenarios death.

In the story, "The Jungle" by Upton Sinclair is about the meat industry and how they were packing spoiled meat in a unsanitary mannor.  It follows a guy by the name of Jonas, who had worked in one of the pickle room among the spoiled meat.  He shares all of the things he wittnessed during this time in the pickle room until he got moved such as packaging old spoiled meat, covering up the aroma with stronger pickle than they used before and  they also used soda to rub on the meat to remove the oder. This story tells you how they covered up their secrets and prevented getting caught. It exposes the harsh condititons of the meatpacking industry in Chicago.

When their meat had turned too spoiled, they "chop it up into sausage." Free meat would previously have been found sour, but meatpackers would use "miracles of chemistry, which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh, or salted." The packers were required to try to get rid of the strong odor comepletely and were given extra money if they succeeded. Some meat that was turned into sausage were "moldy and white - it would be dosed with borax and glycerin." The meat would be stored in piles in rooms with leaks in the ceiling and wandering rats around them. The spoiled meat are served as breakfast after they are turned "fresh".

In the text it talk about how to factory would cover up the smell of rotten meat. For example, in the text it states "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell"(2). Which shows how the meat would be rubbed with soda to take away the oder. It also states "that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption"(3). This showed how by using chemicals it would cover up the moldy white parts.

some ways the factories would use and cover-up spoiled meat was by rubbing an excessive amount of chemicals onto the meat just so the smell of the mold won't be detected by the eater. An example of factory workers drenching the spoiled meat into chemicals can be found on lines 13-15, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters" this is just one of the many ways the factories that produced meat would deal with the spoiled meat, they didn't let anything go unsold. even if it was spoiled.

First, when the factory could not use the spoiled meat for anything else, they "either [canned] it or [chopped] it up into sausage" (Sinclair 1). Second, "they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters" (Sinclair 2). The packers had a strong pickle "which destroyed the odor" (Sinclair 2). The spoiled meat "would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption" (Sinclair 3). The workers sometimes would "spit uncounted billions of consumption germs" (Sinclair 4).

Ways that the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat included rubbing meat that has pickle and had gone sour, with soda in order to take away its oder, and using all the parts of pork and stuffing it into casings, calling it "boneless hams".  Whenever the factory would get old sausages from Europe that were covered in mold, they would drench them in borax and glycerin and mix them in with other meats, and would send them out to stores. Also, they used gelatin on the sausages to make them the color brown, and would stamp "special" on some of them when they were in the process of wrapping and charge two cents more a pound.

There would be several means to cover up and use spoiled meet from inserting pickles into hams to treating meat with chemicals. When it came to sausage it would not matter whether or not meat was spoiled. The factories would just dose the meat with borax and glycerin which would remove the smell and they would sell it. Another thing they would do is use a pickle and insert it into the ham to try and neutralize the sent of it. Finally, another way they tried to cover up spoled meet was by removing the bone of hams and inserting a white-hot iron. This would cause there to be only "Number One Grade" ham which was most expensive for consumers to buy.

The meatpacking that was conducted in the industry in Chicago was disgusting. The author, Upton Sinclair, explained how there were various ways in which the workers in the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat. Some of how workers would use or cover up spoiled meat were the action of rubbing the meat with soda to take away the smell, filling up ham with pickle, the workers also had a stronger pickle that destroyed odor, the invention of a new device by a person to extract the bone, from which the bad part generally lay, and insert in a white-hot-iron. These various ways in which the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat are all discussed in the second paragraph of the excerpt from The Jungle.

There  were various ways the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat. In paragraph four it states "To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as \u201cgiving them thirty per cent.\u201d They would use pickle jucie so the smell would go away. In paragraph three is states " Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference." They would mix the spoiled meat with other meat that wasnt so it wouldn't smell and be able to reuse it.

The factory would use fresh and very old outdated meat and soak them in chemicals to get rid of the smell and chnage the color so that they could still sell the meat. No matter how old the meat was they would use it. The chemicals were there way of covoring up how old it was to be able to sell it. This summerizes how the factory would cover up the spoiled meat and how they used it.

in the text it says "With one member trimming beef in a cannery, and another working in a sausage factory, the family had a first-hand knowledge of the great majority of Packingtown swindles. For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage. With what had been told them by Jonas, who had worked in the pickle rooms, they could now study the whole of the spoiled-meat industry on the inside, and read a new and grim meaning into that old Packingtown jest\u2014that they use everything of the pig except the squeal."

There was a machine that would be used to inject the meat with pickle, which was a perservitive (paragraph 2). The main part of the meat that spoiled the fastest was right around the bone, so they would take that part out and replace it with a hot iron (paragraph 2). The meat that was "smoked" was just covering in borax and colored with geliton to make it look smoked. This was done because smoking the meat took time and money the meat packing plant did not want to use.

The author is telling us how horrible this factory was by stating their vile practices not only towards their meat but their workers as well. Various ways a factory would cover up spoil meat is by rubbing it with soda in order to hide the smell. For example, Upton stated, "they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counter" (Sinclair). Another example is that factory workers had mixed spoiled meat with other meat such as the ham in order to not "watse" the meat. For example Upton also stated, "there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them" (Sinclair). There have been multiple process of the meat had to gone through with chemicals which were added to make the meat "head cheese" in Paragraph 2.

The factory used many different ways to use their spoiled meat. All of these ways were disgusting and should not have been done, but they were to make a profit. When ham was spoiled, they would "extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron" (Sinclair 2). This is absolutely unsanitary but was a trick they used anyways. Another thing they did was cut up spoiled meat into sausage. For example, "whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage" (Sinclair 1). These are two of the many ways factory workers used inhumane ways of selling meat just to make a profit.

Other ways the factory would use the spoiled meat is they would take it and cut it up and then threw it into the grinder along with the good meat however when they did this often rats and poisons were mixed in but the company did nothing to stop it.

They would use pickles to overlap the bad odor of the ham and for the ones that were really really spoild they would use a tecnique called "giving them thirty persent" for this tecnique they would use a stronger pickle that hen distroyed all the bad odor like said in parragraph 2 " To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as \u201cgiving them thirty per cent." The factory would also accept any meat to make a sausage they were mixing up all with other kinds of meat and puting borax and glycerin.

These factories were very unsanitary and so was the food.  "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell."  Even though the quality of the meat wasn't safe for consumption they covered it up. "There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." The meat was covered with toxic chemicals and included spoiled meat. The sanitary conditions of the factory were below standard in every way possible.

Since the meat was spoiled, it let out an awful oder that was so bad you couldnt be in the same room with them. Upton Sinclair states, "To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor- a process known to the workers as "giving them thirty per cent." Then, if the meat looked moldy they had a different process. The article states, "There would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that has been rejected, and that was moldy and white- it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." This shows how the workers didnt care how old the meat was and where it came from, but instead how much they could make and money.

The factory would use a lot of different techniuques to cover the spoiled meat. The author says "meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell" (Sinclair 2). This quote decribes how they would cover the smell of spoiled meat so that they would still be able to sell it. The text also states that meat was "mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference" (Sinclair 3). This excerpt describes how the factory would mix the most spoiled meat into sausages, and nobody would know that they did that. As seen in the text, factories would use many disgusting and unsanitary practices to increase revenue and use every bit of meat they could.

The factory had done a system called pickling hams, which was supposed to preserve them, yet, they were found to be spoiled. One way they would have taken the odor off was to rub it with soda to take the smell away (paragraph 2).  Another one is that if the spoiled meat that has been pickled or gone bad, then they have the bad part cut out and turned into "boneless ham" (paragraph 2).  These were then sold and eaten on free lunch counters. Furthermore,  when the whole meat was bad the meat factories would chop it up with other meat and then add in borax and glycerin into the hoppers to cover up spoiled meat (paragraph  3).  The meat was never taken care of properly and they were disgusting, which led them to use or cover up spoiled meat.

The factory would  rub spoiled meat with soda, pump meats full of pickle, stuff extra bits of meat in wrappings, package joints with very little meat, skin and cook old meat to sell it is top grade, or the bone would be carved out and the meat around it cauterized (Paragraph 2). Extremely spoiled meat would be mixed with other meat until it was impossible to discern the spoiled meat from the other meats (Paragraph 3). Rotten meat would also be covered in borax and glycerin before being made into sausages and sold (Paragraph 3). The water that the factory workers washed their hands in, leaving bits of meat floating in it for several months, was used to make sausages, including all the rotten scraps wached off workers hands in the packaged product (Paragraph 5).

Throughout Sinclair's piece, he describes in great detail how the factory would go to such lengths to cover up any spoiled meat so they could profit from its sale. For instance, even the rats that ran across the meat were not spared as "there were things that went into the sausage in comparison with which a poisoned rat was a tidbit." This example greatly exemplified the magnitude of unsanitary items that were mixed in with the meat. Also, he employs strong diction to describe how the "moldy and white" sausage from Europe was used in conjunction with "borax and glycerin" to mask its odor, taste, and color. This again demonstrates the abysmal standards used in the meat-packing industry at the time, and further shows how the workers went to great lengths to sell the spoiled meat.

The meat factory had many different ways they could use and/or cover-up spoiled meat. For example, paragraph 1 states, "Whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage."  Another example would be paragraph 2 when it says that the packers would often rub the meat up with soda to take away the smell and still sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters in many different varieties.  There were many different ways the workers would cover up the fact that they were selling poisoned meat, one more example being that they "preserved it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown", which is not only unsafe because of the poisoned meat, but also because of the amount of color that was added to it to make it edible for customers.

The workers would cover up the spoiled meat by using the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters and also  chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose.  Another thing they would do is have a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds and also have some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor

The factory would cover up spoiled meat by putting soda to hide the smell , even when the odor is so bad they put stronger pickle which destroyed the odor, they would extract  the bone from the bad parts and insert a white-hot iron and sell and call it boneless hams , whole spoiled ham was cut up mixed with half s ton of other meats and sold as sausages,  often times they would dose moldy and white sausages with borax and glycerin and dumped in hoppers and made over again for home consumption. The numerous ways  that the factory can cover up their spoiled meat would be to rub it with soda to take both the smell and sour to it, giving "any color and any flavor and any odor they chose" (paragraph 2). Another method they used was to pump pickle into meats, such as ham, to hide the odor and "giving them thirty percent". They also had numbered grades One to Three, but with the use of a special contraption they would remove the bone and put "a white-hot iron" (Paragraph 2) into the hole where the bone was to hide the bad parts where the bone used to lay, renaming them Number Ones again. Finally, they reused old hog skins that people would not eat until they chopped it up and false advertised it by relabeling it as "head cheese" (Paragraph 2).

The text shows several ways they would use or cover up spoiled meat. The first example is when Sinclair says "for it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage" (Sinclair 1).. This shows that, instead of throwing away old or spoiled meat, they would can it, or make it into sausages. Another example is when Sinclair is talking about how they never pay attention to what was put in to sausage, and then says "that was mold and white - it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers. and made over again for home consumption" (Sinclair 3). This is again showing how most of the spoiled meat was just washed and put into sausage.

The factories would cover up spoiled meats by doing a number of clever things. For example they would rub it in chemicals to make it seem like it was not spoiled. They would also insert hot irons into the spoiled part to make it look like it was edible. In the text it states "after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Some ways the meatpacking industry would use or cover up spoiled meat would be by canning it, chopping it up into a sausage, extracting the bone and inserting white-hot iron, and rubbing the meat with soda to cover up the smell. For instance, whenever meat was so spoiled it couldn't be used for anything else, they would "can it or else chop it up into sausage". In addition, an ingenious person presented a new device that " would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade\u2014there was only Number One Grade."  This clarifies the various ways the meatpacking industry would cover up and sell unsanitary meat to the American public.

The factory used many different ways to use spoiled meat instead of throwing it out. One way was pumping the meat with a very strong pickle, stronger than the norm. The text says "...here would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor...". Another method was mixing the spoiled meat with good meat. This seems to be the most used method, "It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. ".

"they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters" (paragraph 2 Sinclair).   They would also stick a hot rod into ham that had expired. "after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad.........they would extract the bone.........and insert in the hole a white-hot iron." (paragraph 2 Sinclair).

Pork and beef scraps would be canned and other meats were made into sausages. The first way they would cover up the spoiled meat is by, chopping it up and putting it in meat. When it came to this they had two choices, "...either to can it or else chop it up into sausage" (Sinclair 302). Another way that they used spoiled meat was injecting it with pickle juice. Pickle juice is made of vinegar and salt which help preserve the meat. Upton asks Jonas, a factory worker, and he says, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with the soda to take  away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters..." To cover up spoiled meat the factory would use chemicals like borax to rid the meat of odor. They would also dye it brown so it was not noticeable to the public. Spoiled meat would be pickled or chopped into fine pieces and mixed into sausage. Upton Sinclair reveals that "Some of it they would make into "smoked" sausage \u2013 but as the smoking took time, and was therefore expensive, they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown. All of their sausage came out of the same bowl, but when they came to wrap it they would stamp some of it "special," and for this they would charge two cents more a pound." Even if the meat tasted different due to its rottenness they would cover that up by saying it was smoked and therefore should be worth more.

Sinclair claims that jonas had told him "they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters". Even though they knew it was bad they tries to take away the smell so it would smell normal.Knowing that it was bad they covered it up and sold it even if it could get someone sick

These packing companies would use chemicals and other things like soda to get rid of odor "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. "(Sinclair 2). Workers would also do a process with the meat called "giving them a thirty per cent" pumping the meat with stronger pickle which destroyed the odor  "To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as \u201cgiving them thirty per cent.\u201d (Sinclair 4)

If the meat went bad, many factories would chop it into a sausage that would later be sold. Most of the times they would hide the digusting odor that the meat would obtain, such as rubbing the meat in soda to take away the smell so it could be sold later on. Some of the hams would be given an extra/second pickle in hopes that it would be strong enough to destroy the odor. The workers had called this as "giving them thirty per cent".  They created odd processes as well, such as trying to "extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert it in the hole a white-hot iron". Lastly, they would also try and preserve the meat with borz and color it with gelatin for a browner color, and would even "stamp some it "special", and for this they would charge two cents more a pound".

To cover up the spoiled meat smell and look, they would pickle the spoiled meat and when the meat would be sour hte would rub in some soda to cover it up. Many times they would frequently just mix it in with meat that wasn't spoiled to hid discoloration and smell. They would add vegtetables and many other things just to make it presentable. In the text it states, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose" This quote from the text clearly gives support to the prior summarization.

The industy used as many ways as they could to use all of the meat, even after it was spoiled. They would mash it up with meat that was still good so no one would notice. They would rub it with soda, they chopped up some of the meat and labelled it as something other than what it was. Some of the meat would tumble onto the floor, and this meat would still be used. "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." They would put the spoiled meat in pickle juice and then rub it with soda to take away the smell. I know this becuase in paragraph 2 it says "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell". Evidence from paragraph 3 proves this becuase it says " there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption".

The meatpacking factory would go to great lenghts to produce as much meat as possible, and  the sanitary and moral guidlines where not yet set in place for them. They would often "whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else ... chop it up into sausage" (Sinclair par 1).  This procces would make what they labeled as grade 1 sausage primarily be scraps and spoiled meat soaked in chemicals. Sinclair also mentions "all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose" (Sinclair par 2). The chemist behind the scenes determained the flavour or appearence of the beef and pork that was to be packaged. All that mattered to them was that people bought it, the ethics of what they where doing did not exist.

The factory would use many tactics to try to cover up or use spoilt meat. One way they would use the rotten meat was that they would chop it with sausage to conceal it.  The text states,"...whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage." They would also rub the meat with baking soda to hide the rotten scent," ...the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell...' Another strategy used the disguise the terrible quality is that they would use borax and glycerin in rotten meat.  The text states, "it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption."

The factory would mask the scent of spoiled meat in order to be able to sell it. ". . . they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell [. . .] To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor--a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty per cent'" [2]. The workers would also mix up spoiled meat and other non-meat materials into sausage. "There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor [. . .] rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together. [. . .] there were things that went into the sausage in comparison with which a poisoned rat was a tidbit" [4]. They would also mix preservatives with other meats to prevent them from going bad so quickly with chemicals such as borax and gelatin.

one way that was easy for industry to cover what was actually happening is to have different names for different meats. One way the factories would use or cover up spoiled meat is the pickle method. The meat taken out of pickle would often be sour and spoiled. It would also have a very strong smell. They would use soda to take away the smell and sell it as fresh meat. Nother way they would use old meat was by extracting the bone and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. The "bonless ham" they claimed it to be, wasnt really bonless ham. It was "all the odds and end of pork stuffed into casings; and "California hams", which were shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out;..." (Sinclair 2). Sausages that were white and moldy wouldnt go to waste. Instead they would get shipped to us from Europe and from there the workers would infuse borax and glycerin into them so it would be all good again for "consuming".

Some ways the factory would cover up spoiled meat by canning it, cutting it up into sausages, and soaking them in chemicals. In paragraph 1 it states, "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage." This shows that they can and make sausages out of them, and in paragraph 3 it states, "...old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." This means that when the sausage can't be used anymore they dump them in chemicals to make it seem lke it's fine for comsumption. In conlcusion, factories had disgusting ways of getting rid of spoiled meat by, making it seem like it is safe for consumption.

The factories would use many deplorable means to use and cover spoiled meat such as filling it with pickle and rub soda on it, "meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell." They would also take bad ham, remove the bone, heat up the inside with an iron and then sell it to consumers. Finally, the most atrocious method they used would be how they dealt with vermin that contaminated their meat. They would poison bread which would kill the vermin, but they also mixed the dead rats and poisoned bread with the new meat, effectively doing nothing to solve the problem. This is no fairy story and no joke; the meat would be shoveled into carts, and the man who did the shoveling would not trouble to lift out a rat even when he saw one \u2013 there were things that went into the sausage in comparison with which a poisoned rat was a tidbit."

In the exerpt from the text "The Jungle," Upton Sinclair exposes the unsanitary conditions found in meatpacking factories during the early 20th century in America. To cover up these atrocities, meatpackers used various techniques. Among these are pumping spoiling hams with a "much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor . . . ." They also took whole hams that had gone completely bad and "Cut [them] up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute flyers, and mixed [them] with half a ton of other meat, [so that] no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference." In other cases, when there was "old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white -- it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over . . . ." These are just some of the many things done to hide the horrible meat produced from the factories.

They would pickle the meat so it would last longer, and get rid of the odor."To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty per cent.' "(Sinclair 2). After they did that they would rub baking soda n the pig or the meat to hide the terrible  odor. "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell..."( Sinclair 2). Later in time when the meat would be so spoiled and rotten they made a machine to extract the bone and cook the inside of the meat where the meat was most likey spoiled. "later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron."(Sinclair 2).

The meat industry was very disgusting . They came to the point that they would sell dirty meat in order to recieve money. To make "smoked" sausage for the publics breakfast they made fake smoked sausage and just colored it brown,"Some of it they would make into "smoked" sausage \u2013 but as the smoking took time, and was therefore expensive, they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown." When it came to the meat it would always spoil to to solve it the decided to put them in pickle only so find out the desturbing smell made things worse ."meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose". They were smart but still not clean .

The Factory would try to cover up or flat out hide the fact that the meat was spoiled. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as \u201cgiving them thirty percent.\u201d This tells us that the factory had not only numerous way to cover up the meat being spoiled, but was also able to put the meat out and sell to the public.  Showing that the factories were truly something else and had very clever ways to make me appear to be unspoiled.

In The Jungle, when meat was spoiled it could be chopped into pieces for sausage, it could be put i. a can, given a new name to make up for its new appearance, or it would be cleaned with chemicals so that it could be edible again. "whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage\u2026fancy 'skinned hams,' which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no one would buy them\u2014that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled 'head cheese!'...Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption.". The Jungle  exsposes various ways that the meatpackig industry would use or cover up spoiled meat during the Industrial Revolution. The text mentions that "whenever meat was so spoiled... could not be used for anything else... ca it or chop it up into sausage" (Siclair par. 1). This spoiled meat should have been thrown out, for eating it would make people sick, but instead the industry found ways around throwing out the spoiled meat. The sausage that contained it would be eaten by the public and exposed them to serious illness, but they were oblivious to what they were eating. When workers found sour meat from pickling, they would "rub it up with soda to take away the smell... sell it to be eated on free-lunch counters" (Sinclair par. 2). Yet again, meat that was unfit to be eaten would still go through production and be sold to the public. The industry refused to throw away any meat, and did whatever it took to convice the public that what they were buying was edible. The meatpacking industry used various methods to cover up spoiled meat and distribute it to the public.

They would use some liquid to make the spoiled meat seem like fresh meat, as stated in the article,"To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor"(Paragraph 2). They would then take the more evident part of the meat away to not rise any suspiscion, "...now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade\u2014there was only Number One Grade."(Paragraph 2). Then they used chemicals in order to hide the rancid flavor, "...it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption."(Paragraph 3). To finally mix it with fresh meat so it isn't noticeable, "...and cartload after cartload of it would be taken up and dumped into the hoppers with fresh meat, and sent out to the public's breakfast."(Paragraph 5).

The factory would do anything to cover up spoiled meat to sell to the public to make profit. The factory only cares about making money so they would use any and all meat possible. This meat can be spoiled, rotten, moldy, poisoned, etc. This can be shown in the text by it stating, " For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage". This shows that when a certain meat was labeled as spoiled they would send it to get put into a can for canned meat or it would be processed into a sausage. It also states in the text, "There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption". This shows that when a meat was moldy they would rub certain things on the meat to cover up the moldy appearance. This is how the factory would cover up spoiled meat.

The factory depicted by Upton Sinclair used various ways to use or cover up spoiled meat such as filling the ham with pickle juice,  and replacing spoiled bones with hot irons. For example, "saved time and increased the capacity of the plant\u2014a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds."(Sinclair 2). Machinery was used to inject the spoiled hams with pickle juice in order to save money. The pickle juice was used to mask the smell and taste of spoiled meat to make the factory more money for less effort. Another example of the factorie's methods is "extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron."(Sinclair 2). A new device was invented that could remove the contaminated bones of the meat that lowered the quality. The bone was replaced with iron, so the factory could make more money selling "higher quality" meat products. That is how the factory in The Jungle  used  wicked means to cover up and sell spoiled meat at the public's expense to make more profit.

The factory would cover up the spoiled meat in various ways. One of the ways they would cover it up was to cover up the smell with soda and chemistry things. This would hide that the meat was bad unles someone was testing the meat. (Sinclair 2). The factory would also remove the parts of the meat that were visably bad. They would cut it out and cut it a different way. They would grind up the meat into small pieces and no one could tell what was really in them.  In conclusion, the factory had many ways to use or cover up the spolied meat.

The Meat packing industry was filled with several unsanitary factories. Oftentimes, the meat processed at the factory would spoil and the employees would cover up the meat and move on. In Paragraph 1, the text states, "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage." Factories would manage to hide the spoiled food into sausage or in other cans of meat. However, the meat would leave a lingering, foul smell so more attempts to hide the use of spoiled meat were put into motion. Paragraph 2 includes, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." The factories not only managed to cover the apperance of the spoiled meat but also the smell with attempts of rubbing soda on the pounds of food. These various cover ups  evidently lead to the Meat Inspection Act to prevent the selling of spoiled meat in our economy today.

In Upton Sinclair's novel "The Jungle," Sinclair illustrated the different ways  factories would cover up spoiled meat by listing that plants often brine different meats or  cut those kinds of meat into many thousand pieces by machine, then the meat will rotate. sausage or beef. In addition, Sinclair extended the idea of \u200b\u200bmarinating meat by stating "To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as \u201cgiving them thirty per cent.\u201d This highlights that factories will keep the ham even after  a long period of spoilage and sell it to  American consumers. Furthermore, Sinclair also extended the idea of \u200b\u200bthe sausage process by stating. "It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference." After further explanation, Sinclair describes the idea of \u200b\u200bfactories cutting parts of meat, especially ham,  to remove their odors and keep consumers satisfied.

"Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. In the pickling of hams, they had an ingenious apparatus,1 by which they saved time and increased the capacity2 of the plant\u2014a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with a pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as \u201cgiving them thirty percent.\u201d Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad."

The meatpacking industry would use any means to sell the meat putting it in sausage, mixing it with other meat, and  covering up with rotten parts with chemicals and gelatin to make it look presentable to eat. Some of these inlcude when the text stated "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else chop it up into sausage" Sinclair 1). In this quote Sinclair describes what meatpackers would do if the meat was too spoiled for regular consumtion. He says they would chop it up and hide it with other meat into sausage so its rotten contents couldn't be detected. Another quote about what they did with spoiled meat was "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell" (Sinclair 2). Here the author talks about a time when someone described what they did to the meat chemically to preserve the authenticity in its look of edibility. Overall the meatpacking companies would use different techniques such as putting it in sausage and chemically altering it to mask its condition to make profit off meat that couldn't or wouldn't be normally consumed.

Some of the ways the factory would cover up spoiled meat were: If the meat was spoiled and the odor was bad they would pickle it to hide the order. "Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. One way that the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat was to pickle them, rub it with soda to make it smell better (ot any smell of their choosing), and then sell it to people. " ...the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters...the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose.". The factory would also pump a second type of stronger pickle to kill the odor of spoiled meat and smoke it. Various ways the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat was by taking sausage that was spoiled and adding or removing features of the meat.  To demonstrate, Upton Sinclair states, "...the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell," This indicates a waay the factory would cover up spoiled meat was by editing the odor of the meat with soda for it to be free for people, even though it's spoiled and basically every part of the pig. The factory uses spoiled meat in various ways. It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white\u2014it would be dosed with borax and glycerine, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption. There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together.

The meatpacking industy would use cover up spoiled meat by mixing it with other meats, or chemically fixed the meats. The meatpacking factory had found many solutions to use or cover up spoiled meat. For instance, when meat that was taken out of pickle was "found sour," instead of scrapping the meat, the company decided to "...rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free lunch counters" (Sinclair). In addition, when hams that were pickled were found spoiled, some of them with, "...an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them," (Sinclair), a second pickle would instead be pumped into the same meat, which destroyed the odor. This process, so often used in the meatpacking industry, became known to the workers as "giving them thirty per cent" (Sinclair). Lastly,  the industry would relabel products after working on the meat to make the odor, bacteria, or old parts of the meat go away, creating products such as "boneless hams", which were "odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings," or even "skinned hams," labeled as fancy, which were made of the oldest pigs, with heavy and coarse skin, "...that no one would buy-that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled "head cheese!"" (Sinclair).
