The factory used various ways to use and cover up spoiled meat. For example, when the meat would become spoiled they would "rub it up with soda to take away the smell" (Source 1). They used this in order to continue selling this spoiled meat despite the fact that it was unhealth. The factory would just take away the smell to cover up the fact that it was old. Continuing, whenever Europe would send back "old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin" (Source 1) so that it could be sent back out. They ensured that they weren't losing money on this dirty, old sausag. By using chemicals they could still use the spoiled meat. Moreover, the factory stored barrels and "the barrels would be dirt and rust and old nails and stale water \u2013 and cartload after cartload of it would be taken up and dumped into the hoppers with fresh meat" (Source 1). This would happen once a year, meaning this meat and grime would sit for a year and then they would sell it to the people. They didn't care about anything but getting the money from this soiled meat. The factory would do anything and put any chemical or trick on the meat in order to use or cover up the spoiled meat.

The factory is an environment that is unsafe due to its repulsive conditions and practices. Those factors are what caused the meat to be spoiled and contaminated. But regardless of the hazardous conditions, the meat had gone under, the factory still had to make a profit. One of the ways the spoiled meat was covered up was a process in which the bone was removed and in place would be a hot iron. "but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white hot-iron" (paragraph 2).  The bone needed to be removed from the spoiled meat since that is mainly where the spoiledness would be located. Another way the spoiled meat would be preserved is in a casing. "...all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings" (Paragraph 2). Every piece of the spoiled ham would be put into a casing in which the factory would market it as a "boneless ham" (paragraph 2).  One more way the spoiled meat was concealed is by altering its scent and appearance. "... and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown" (paragraph 5). The spoiled meat would be maintained because of the ingredient borax while the gelatin would change the sickening features of the meat.

In paragraph 2, it states that "the meat was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell". This was one of the ways in which the factory would cover up spoiled meat, because they would attempt to disguise the smell of the meat. In paragraph 3 it states "when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference". This shows yet another way in which the factory would use spoiled meat, by cutting it up so that fresh meat could be mixed with a small amount of the spoiled meat, thus disguising the spoiled meat. In paragraph 4, it also states that "There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it". This quote demonstrates how the factory would use meat that is being contaminated by the factory conditions and habits. However, this meat was continued to be used to sell in the future.

In the meatpacking industry, the workers would use certain methods, such as taking the bones out of rotten ham or pickling the ham to reduce the odor.  Sinclair states that "some ingenious person had hit upon a new device" where they would "extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay" in order to get rid of grades for the meats (Sinclair 2). Even though a bad part of the meat was being extracted, the way it was done was still unsanitary and it was used as a scheme by the meatpacking industry to appeal to the greater population. The meatpacking industry found another way to increase productivity by "fill[ing] a ham with pickle in a few seconds" through the process of using a "needle into the meat and working with his foot" in order to make the meat last longer, even at the cost of ruining its sanitation (Sinclair 2). The fact that the workers would use their feet in the process indicated how the meatpacking industry was corrupt when it came to providing sanitary ham's to the population and that it would find any way possible to increase productivity and cover-up spoiled meat. In Excerpt From The Jungle by Upton Sinclair, light is shed on the corrupt practices of the meat industry as they would taken the bones out of rotten ham and pickle ham to reduce the odor in attempts to cover it up from the rest of the population.

They did various things with spoiled meat. They would can it or chop it into sausage if it wasn't too spoiled. If they took it out of the pickle and it was sour they would rub it with soda to take the smell away and sell it. When they used the machine to pickle the ham there were still some that came out sour. Some of them were too sour to stand. Then they would pump the sour ham with an even stronger pickle that got rid of the smell. For the hams, they would stuff odds and ends of pork into casings. California hams were shoulders, knuckle joints, and most of the meat cut out. The skinned hams were old hogs that were tough and no one bought until it was cooked and chopped to be head cheese. When the whole ham was spoiled they mixed it with good meat and canned.  The moldy sausage that came from  Europe was dosed with borax and glycerin. They sent it out to shops again.  Poisoned rats went in the sausage along with the spoiled chopped up meat. The waste barrels were cleaned out once in a while and mixed with fresh meat to go to shops.  Some of it would be made into smoked sausage. They would rub it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it look brown and sell it. All of these methods were disgusting. You never knew what you were going to get. It was a pork surprise.

In order to cover up spoiled meat, the factory would do the bare minimum. In the second paragraph, it says "To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty percent.'" These factories would put spoiled meat products in with fresh products to level it out and help them go unnoticed. These factories would also take out parts of the ham to resell it at top value. Also in the second paragraph, it says "later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade\u2014there was only Number One Grade." By making meats boneless these companies and factories would be able to avoid the bad quality labels and would be able to get away with a possibly dangerous health risk.  These factories would grind up meats and animal products that had gone bad in order to support the high demand and save money, despite the potential harm that this process has on customers. This can be supported by a sentence in the third paragraph that says "Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference."

The factory would often use methods such as chemicals to atempt to neutralize the smell of the spoiled meat, or a stronger pickle to put in the hams to destroy the odor. Some people would extract the bone from where the bad smell was located and it usually killed of the scent, " And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as \u201cgiving them thirty per cent.\u201d Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as \u201cNumber Three Grade,\u201d but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade\u2014there was only Number One Grade. The packers were always originating such schemes\u2014they had what they called \u201cboneless hams,\u201d which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; "(The Jungle).

There were various things that the factory would do to cover up and essentially use the spoiled meat that they had. One manner in which they practiced this was by rubbing the meat with soda to take away the smell, as stated in paragraph two.  The workers would also pickle their meat to get rid of the odor but if it was very pungent, they had a second and much stronger pickle which helped destroy the smell, which the workers called, "giving them thirty per cent." Along with this, they would label the packages in many ways to make it look like it was "original" even if they were made out of meat parts that were not supposed to be used. Another form in which they would use and cover-up spoiled meat would be by getting spoiled whole ham and old sausage with mold from Europe and dosing it with borax and glycerin, where it would then be dumped into hoppers and made over again for packaging. Mice, feces, poisoned bread, dirt, diseases, and sawdust were just a few things that would be processed in the hoppers along with the spoiled meat. Lastly, they would also use their chemistry department to make sausages appear brown-with the use of borax and colored gelatin- and labeled it "smoked" sausage after their practice of smoking sausage became expensive for the factory.  In all, the actions in which the factory practiced were extremely unsanitary and do not appear today thanks to the Meat Inspection Act.

The excerpt describes many ways that the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat.  One way was to grind up the meat and use it for sausage as the consumer could not detect the spoiled nature this way.  The text states ". For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage."  Another way that the factory covered up spoiled meat was by rubing it in chemicals to get rid of the smell.  " the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose."   Furthermore,  the author states that there were various ways that each part of a pig was covered-up after spoiling but after the whole pig was spoiled, it was all used for sausage.   The text states "It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference."  As is evident, the factory did not care about the health of consumers.

Since it was the custom, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage. It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white, it would be dosed with borax and glycerine, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption. There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together.

The factory took advantage of packaging. The text states, " To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as \u201cgiving them thirty per cent.\u201d Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as \u201cNumber Three Grade,\u201d but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade\u2014there was only Number One Grade. The packers were always originating such schemes\u2014they had what they called \u201cboneless hams,\u201d which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and \u201cCalifornia hams,\u201d which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy \u201cskinned hams,\u201d which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no one would buy them\u2014that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled \u201chead cheese!\u201d

The meatpacking industry came up with many creative ways to hide the fact their meat was spoiled. One way is that they would simply just chop it up and use it for sausage, "whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage" (Sinclair 1). If the meat was so gross and spoiled that it could not be used for anything else they would just use it, along with any other meat they could not use, for sausage. For meat that was spoiled that only had a smell, they would use chemicals or soda to cover the smell, "they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell" (Sinclair 2). Another way to cover the small was to sell it as pickled meat, "the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor" (Sinclair 2). A lot of the meatpacking industries would send their meat to other countries like Europe to be sold there, some places in Europe would have to send it back because the meat was too old and spoiled. When this happened all the packing industries would load it with chemicals to be sent back, "it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption" (Sinclair 3). This shows how poorly the meatpacking business takes care of their work environment and how much they do not care about the people who consume their products.

The meat packing industries of America found numerous ways to cover up the fact that they would sell spoiled meat.  In paragraph two it states, "Jonas told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smel.." it also states later in that same paragraph, "...by  plugnign this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds.  And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spolied, some of them with an ordor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them." Later in life there was a new method, they would take out the bone and replace it with a white-hot iron. Over time the pacheres organized, what were called, "schemes." One scheme was called the "boneless ham. " Paragraph two states, "...what they called "boneless hams," which they were all the odds and ends of posk stuffed into casings." Many more awful schemes were made. Some involved the whole ham being spoiled and others involved awful parts of the pig to be cased as a stomach-disasting mixture. When sausage was made and it came back from Europe rejected and moldy white, companies covered the sausage in borax and glycerin before being made all over again from humans.

It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white\u2014it would be dosed with borax and glycerine, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption. There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. The factories would use various ways to cover up spoiled meat. "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." [2] This quote explains how even when the meat had become sour and smelly, the factory would use methods like rubbing soda on it and chemicaly altering the meat. "Under the system of rigid economy which the packers enforced, there were some jobs that it only paid to do once in a long time, and among these was the cleaning out of the waste barrels. Every spring they did it; and in the barrels would be dirt and rust and old nails and stale water \u2013 and cartload after cartload of it would be taken up and dumped into the hoppers with fresh meat, and sent out to the public's breakfast." [5] This quote details how barrels filled with waste and non-edible substances would be thrown into hoppers full of fresh meat to then be fed to the public. These quotes summarize how the meatpacking industry and factories did not care whether the food was safe or even food at all. Anything that could be presented as food, dangerous or not would be sold to people in order to make extra cash.

It's no doubt that the factory was deceitful to the public when it came to the meat pre-eration but they also endangered the public by using hazardous and unsanitary practices. In the article it states that they used practices such as "There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs." These practices were not limited to the unsanitary environment that the employees had to work under. having no place to wash their hands influenced the employees into "washing them in the water that was to be ladled into the sausage." These quotes create an emphasis on the unsanitary practices. when it came to the meat however it became more and more apparent that the factory did not care about ethical practices because it was about the money. " These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together." This would create more meat and it would get rid of the rats therefore it was seen as a good thing to do. meat that was spoiled would be mixed in with good meat and covered with chemicals in order to prevent awareness of the fact that it was really bad meat. Another form of covering up rotten meat would be taking out the bone where the rotten part was found and inserting a white-hot iron. this would erase the visible trace of rotten and or spoiled meat.

The factor used many different techniques to cover up the fact that they were still handing out spoiled meat to people. They knew of the meat being spoiled and gross but they still used different chemicals to "clean" it to be able to still package it and sell it. If there was every a spoiled piece of meat, "they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose" (paragraph 1). Just so they could sell more meat they would rub a different mixture of items to make it sellable again so so they don't lose money. another technique they used was, " some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron" (paragraph 2). Not knowing what they are inserting they would still place the hot rod in the meat to make it seem like nothing was wrong with it. There were other things they did to cover up that the meat was spoiled but still be able to sell it to make a profit and even though all of these techniques were different they all had the same job and that was to make spoiled, moldy, and smelly meat look good as new and still sell it to people to make their money, or even to get rid of it.

The meat factory worked in unsanitary conditions  and altered meat to cover up its spoiledness in order to fool the public and make profit. One of the ways the factory covered up the meat was by injecting chemicals that would change the smell, taste, and look of it. According to the text, "...how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any soft of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any ordor they chose" (Sinclair 2). Baking soda would be used on the meat to eliminate the terrible odor of the spoiled meat. The factory would also inject a pickle which would eliminate the smell of the hams as well. The author states, "To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor- a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty-percent' " (Sinclair 3). A needle filled with stronger pickle, compared to the pickle they used on freshmeat, would be injected to the ham. The text states, "Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute-flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference." Spoiled ham would also be mixed in with  fresh meat in order to trick the public into thinking they woere only purchasing fresh meat.

The  meat factory is terrible because they would take spoiled meat and mix it with regular meat and sell it. It's unhealthy and unsafe, people could get sick or get a disease that could kill them.  According to the text," whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage. This just explains what they did with the spoiled meat and how they still sold it. The smell was so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. They pumped the meat into these packers to destroy the odor. In the text, it states, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose."This tells you how they pumped the meat and destroyed the odor. With the help of Sinclar and Jonas, the shameful conditions that once occurred in Chicago's meatpacking industry had been caught. Specifically, Sinclar reveals the immoral actions that transpired in an attempt to cover up spoiled meat.  Sinclar indicates that the factories covered up spoiled meat through masking odors, reusing rejected meat, and combining normal meat and rat meat simply out of pure laziness. For example, Sinclar states that the meat "would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." That quote in itself explains one of the many attempts in which the factories hid their corrupt techniques. Additionally, Sinclar incorporates vivid and descriptive imagery to illustrate the masked meatpacking process. Sinclar states, "There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms, and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats." The explanation regarding the rats and the leaky rooms emphasizes the feeble conditions located in the specific offices. Another way in which the factory workers hid their spoiled meat was by supplementing odorous pickles to the most spoiled portions of meat. This was done in an attempt to mask the stench of the meat. Overall, Sinclar uses tone and imagery to illustrate the corrupt business done by meatpacking workers.

In the excerpt from the 1906 novel,"The Jungle" by Upton Sinclair, it states the various ways the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat. In the text it states, " Jonas told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed..." (Sinclair par.2).  From the text it's shown that the workers would use baking soda to take away the strong odor of the sour meat, and even used chemistry to give it a more fresh taste and odor. This method saved the company money, but was wrong because it was selling people spoiled meat that could possibly make them sick. In paragraph 2 it also states, "... some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle with destroyed the odor--a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty percent'" (Sinclair par.2). When the stench from the meat was bad enought workers would also use a machine to fill the meat with pickle to help rid of the odors. They would use much stronger pickle, and still end up selling the spoiled meat. In the end, the ways they would cover up the spoiled meat is by using baking soda, pickle, or chemistry to help rid of the odors to sell spoiled meat to consumers.

To start off, the factory would use or cover up meat by injecting chemicals into the ham to take away the odor and to either skin the animal or chop out the bones, especially the bad meat surrounded by a particular bone. Plus using machines made the meat more plump and juicy.  Also they would even cook up tiny bits of skin as head of cheese. California hams were the meat that took up the animal's shoulder which were real tough. The text says, "rub soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters.  "Boneless hams,\u201d which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed; and \u201cCalifornia hams,\u201d which were the shoulders and big knuckle joints. Fancy \u201cskinned hams,\u201d were made of oldest hogs, whose skins were heavy that no one would buy. Until cooked and chopped and labeled \u201chead cheese! The machines consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; this needle plunged  into meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds." This demonstrates the idea of how all employees within a factory process the meat by using these different working methods. To summarize, a few ways that helped the factory to make it more efficent was by covering up the ghastly smell, using machinery to help workers, and taking out the bad meat from the inside. Of course, there are a couple of other systems like combining other meat together to make sausages.

The factory would often mask the smell of the spoiled meat by "giving them thirty percent", which used a pump that was stronger than usual to destroy the smell. They would also rub soda on the meat at times to take away the spoiled smell, Sinclar says, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters." Another way they would cover up spoiled meat would be taking the bone out and replacing it with a white-iron rod, as Sinclair states, "after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad... they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron", and then they would label these as "boneless hams", getting rid of the three level grading scale. In order to cover up spoiled meat, the factory would also just mix it in with non spoiled meat, to make it look like they had used one-hundred percent non spoiled meat. The factory would also take in old sausage that had been rejected and use chemicals to mask the spoilage, and then reuse it, Sinclair goes more in depth when he says, "there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption."

Upton Sinclair strengthens his argument that conditions were unsanitary in meat processing factories through describing the various ways in which workers would use or cover up spoiled meat. This included suppressing the odor through the use of borax and glycerin, adding more meat to cover the spoiled meat, filling hams with pickle, chopping spoiled meat to make "sausage", selling bad hams as "Number Three Grade", and through extracting the bone of bad ham and selling it as boneless ham. Since spoiled meat had a very strong odor to it, workers within factories had to ensure that consumers would not be able to smell it so that they would be more likely to buy and consume it. As a result, they used sweet smelling or odorless products in order to mask the stench. Hams were pickled with a machine that was both quick and effective, but would sometimes spoil the meat further. This detail further helped to support Sinclair's claim that factories mainly cared about making a profit rather than the health of their consumers. Additionally, factory workers used methods of hiding or covering up spoiled meat by making it more subtle through covering it with unspoiled meat or chopping it into smaller pieaces so it would go unnoticed by consumers. Lastly, Sinclair describes how spoiled ham was especially covered up through selling bad ham as "Number Three Grade" or "smoked ham". Later however, "they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron" (Sinclair 1906). This would eliminate the title of "Number Three Grade" in favor of "boneless ham".

The Factory would use various ways to cover up spoiled meat. One of the ways they would cover it up is by chopping it up into sausage.  The narrator says, "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage. " (Sinclair 1). Another way the factory would cover up the spoild meat was, "the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell..." (Sinclair 2). Jonas, a person who had worked in the factory told them they would do this instead of throwing the meat away. The factory would also cut up the moldy meat, meat dropped on the floor, rats, and other going bad foods, put them into the hoppers and made over again to sell.  Finally, the narrator says, "Some of it they would make into "smoked" sausage \u2013 but as the smoking took time, and was therefore expensive, they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown. All of their sausage came out of the same bowl, but when they came to wrap it they would stamp some of it "special," and for this they would charge two cents more a pound." The factory would mix everything together and sell for a higher price, tricking the people into beleiveing that it was a higher ranked meat. This is all of the ways that the factory would cover up the spoiled meat.

The various ways the factory could use or cover up spolied meat include mixing it with frsh meat, dousing it in chemicals, or just mixing anything and everything together to make sausages. "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage."(1) One way they cover up spoiled meat is to chop it up and mix it with other meat so that it can't be seen that it's spolied Another of many ways the factories can sectretly use spoiled meat in their products is by dousing it with chemicals to make it appear fresh, "...also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. " This quotes shares how the factories can simply make any meat look good no matter how old or molded it is. A third way that the factories can use spolied meat is by making it into sausages, "There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption."(3) The repulsive truth behind the making of sausagaes is explained in this quote, also adding to the explination of the factories simply coering their products in chemicals to sell again.

The factory used all types of ways that they could come up with to make use of the spoiled meat for profit. They would rub the spoiled meat with soda to take away the smell, plunge a a needle into the meat and fill the spoiled hams with stronger pickle to destroy the odor, extract the bone and insert a white hot iron to replace it, "boneless hams" being stuffed with all odds of pork and the old sausage that had been rejected in Europe would come all the way back being moldy and white and the factory would dose it with borax and glycerin, dump it into the hoppers and make it over again, the meat would not only be spoiled but would often be seen lying in a pile of dirt and rat feces and poisoned bread all being processed together and much more... The following quoted lines display the misdeeds and alchemy performed by the meat packing industry-  \u201cCalifornia hams,\u201d which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy \u201cskinned hams,\u201d which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no one would buy them\u2014that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled \u201chead cheese!\u201d To sum it up spoiled meat was decorated with disgusting alternatives and sold to the nation as "Number One Grade" meat. All of the doings pointed towards the factory's interest of making money through hook or crook and their lack of care for the health of neither their workers nor the nation.

The various ways the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat is atrocious, from deadrats in the meat, to soda as a flavoring, it only gets worse. In the text it says, "whenever the meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else , either to can it or chop it up into sausage. With what had been told them by Jonas, who had worked in the pickle rooms, they could now study the whole of the spoiled meat industry on the inside, and read a new and grim meaning into that old Packingtown jest-that they used everything of the pig except the squeal. "(paragraph 1). This shows that the factory would use unsanitary spoiled meat and even use parts of the animal that were not edible. A few other ways the factory would use and cover up spoiled meat where, rubbing meat with soda,  spoiled meat soaked in pickle, dead rats would be thrown into the meat since all the meat sat on the floor, and they even used borax and color meat with gelatin to make it looked "smoked". In the text it says, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." (paragraph two). This shows that the factory would try anything to cover up the spoiled meat and horrible odor, even just to make more money.

The factories would do many things to make money of rancid meat. One thing they would do is mix the sour meat withthe good meat to make sausages.  "There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." (paragraph 3) Additionally, there were a lot of chemicals put in the meat to make it look and smell fresh, but in reality it was not. " the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." (paragraph 1) The storage of meat was also unacceptable, meat was just laying around aimlessly. "There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats." (paragraph 4)

Meat butchering factories used many different unsanitary and unlawful practices to cover up spoiled meat. Factories used spoiled meat in sausage as the smell wouldnt be affected greatly becuase of the wuantity of meat being ground. Factories used soda to rub away the smell of rot o meats. Factories also filled hams with pickle to make them stop smelling. Factories also extracted the bones and inserted burning hot metal rods into meat to burn away the most rotted parts of the meat. I know this becuase the text says this, " the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell ...  a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor...Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as \u201cNumber Three Grade,\u201d but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade\u2014there was only Number One Grade. The packers were always originating such schemes"

There was various ways the factory would use and cover up spoiled meat. One way the factory did this in the beginning was by chopping it up and making it into sausage. In the text it says the meat couldn't be used for anything else so sausage was their last resort. Another way they covered up spoiled meat was by using chemicals. In the text it says "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of picle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." This goes to show chemicals played a role in the process, but not only did they make it into sausage and use chemicals, they also would pump the meat. Over time the factory gained control over a second pickle one much stronger than the first and this one got rid of the odor of the meat completely making the price rise thiry cents because the meat didn't smell. Although the meat was already contaminated and spoiled enough, they even furthered and used the skin of the oldest hogs. This skin wasn't very appealing to the eye or probably the sense of touch so they would chop it up into finer pieces and call it "head cheese". The last process of the factory occured when the meat was completely spoiled mold and all. The text says "it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption.". This is the last way the factory covered up their spoiled meat.

There are various ways that they had covered up the spoiled meet. One of those ways is that the spoiled meat that was not pickeld or taken out of the pickle would be covered with soda to take away to smell. Evidence to support this is, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters;" Another way they covered up spoiled meat was that they pumped much stronger pickle into the ham to destroy the oder of the spoiled meat. "To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty per cent.'" Also, another way is they would take out the bone where the bad part is and insert a white-hot iron into the ham. Proof of this is, "Formerly these had been sold as \u201cNumber Three Grade,\u201d but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron." A fourth way they would do this is that they would cut the meat up and mix it with a half a ton of other meat, send it all the way back to Europe where they covered it with borax and glycerin and made it all over again  for home consumption. Evidence of this is, "it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." This all shows how they would cover up spoiled meat and sell it to people without worrying if it would make them sick.

The factory would use a variety of ways to cover up the spoiled meat. First, when the meat came out of pickle it would be sour so they would rub it with soda to get rid of the smell to be able to sell it. They would also perform any "miracle" of chemistry, "giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose" (Sinclair p 2). To save time and increase their capacity, they used a machine that would be able to pickle a ham in a few seconds, but would sometimes leave the hams spoiled with a disgusting odor. To solve this issue, the packers used a stronger pickle. After smoking the hams, some would be found to have gone bad but were still sold to the public as "Number Three Grade". To solve this problem, they decided to extract the bone and insert a white-hot iron, getting rid of all but Number One Grade. To be able to keep selling to the general public, the packers made up numerous schemes and "they had what they called 'boneless hams,' which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and 'California hams,' which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy 'skinned hams,' which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no  one would buy them--that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled 'head cheese!'" (Sinclair p 2). When the whole ham was spoiled, it went to another department where they would mix it with half a ton of other meat, even if the other meat was moldy and white, and then it would be dosed with borax and glycerin.

The factories would use products such as borax, glycerin, and soda to mask the smell and moldy sausages.  "there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." (3) Sinclair explains that these factories are willing to risk the health of many human beings for some more money. Not only are the factories willing to do this but the employees aswell.  Looking at this question of whether or not to use supplies to contaminate meat seems like a very simple answer. However, to the factory workers in the twentieth century, it was not. Not only was it not a simple answer there was no question.  "There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it ... . It was too dark in these storage places to see well ... There was no place for the men to wash their hands before they ate their dinner" (4-5) Sinclair goes on to explain that there was not an option for the workers, and the factory owners knew this.  They knew the workers needed the money to provide for their families.  To add to the atmosphere of the factories Sinclair says, "With one member trimming beef in a cannery, and another working in a sausage factory, the family had a first-hand knowledge" (1) The people were scared to step up for fear of backlash from their "family".   This is another example of things that factory owners used to control and cover up spoiled meat.  Using supplies such as borax, glycerin, and soda and creating a toxic work environment are two examples of methods factories used to cover up spoiled meat.

Factories used various methods to use or cover up spoiled meat during the gilded age some of these methods include, "they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown. "All of their sausage came out of the same bowl, but when they came to wrap it they would stamp some of it 'special,' and for this they would charge two cents more a pound." This was not only disgusting, it was also dangerous as these chemicals could harm you and even cause death. "In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus, by which they saved time and increased the capacity of the plant\u2014a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty per cent." "Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as 'Number Three Grade,' but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade\u2014there was only Number One Grade." This was disgusting as what should've been qualified as "Number Three Grade" which meant that the meat had gone bad was instead qualified as a "Number One Grade" even though the meat was bad and dangerous.

There are plenty of ways that this factory would cover up spoiled meat. One way was by using the spoiled meat, dousing it in chemicals, and repackaging it, and selling it to their consumers. The sausage, "...was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption" (Sinclair 3). This factory was only focused on making as much money as possible by, "...stamping some of it "special," and for this they would charge two cents more a pound" (Sinclair 5) and not caring about the cleanliness or literal hazard that selling this sausage was. Additionally, other conditions were that, "...there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them"(Sinclair 2). To cover this issue up, they would rub sode on the meat to try to deordorize it. Yet, that not working shows how gross the meat really was. The workers did not wash their hands- they did not even have the ability to do so, and they spit all over the food. There was absolutely no sense of sterilization as, "...making a practice of washing them in the water that was to be ladled into the sausage. There were the butt-ends of smoked meat, and the scraps of corned beef, and all the odds and ends of the waste of the plants, that would be dumped into old barrels in the cellar and left there" (Sinclair 5). To cover this up, they would trick their consumers and re-color the meat with broax and gelatin to make it look a presentable color. Their main goal was to obtain more profit; the factory used and re-used disgusting, sickening, spoiled meat and sold it like there was no issue with it.

The Jungle by Upton Sinclair explains several processes by which violations of the meatpacking happened. Meat factory workers would prepare rotten and diseased meat with better meats. The unpleasant pork fat and beef scraps will be packed or canned like chicken. Many of these meats would be chopped up to make sausage. "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage." (Paragraph 1, lines 5-7).  "It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." (Paragraph 3, lines 34-39). "There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms, and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together. " (Paragraph 4, lines 40-45).

The factory would use or cover up spoled meat by changing the way it looks or smells in order to sell the meat. In paragraph 2 it states, "To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as \u201cgiving them thirty per cent.\u201d This quote is explaing how the factory would have its workers would pump chemicals into the meat in order to remove the smell so they could sell the meat. This contributes to how the factoyr would cover up spoiled meat because they put their workers through varuous vigorius processes in order to make the meat up to standard to sell. In paragrpah 2 it also states, "Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as \u201cNumber Three Grade,\u201d but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. " This quote explains how now the factory was finding loopholes in order to salvage spoiled meat any way possible. This connects with hwo the factory tried to cover up spoiled meat because now they would insert a hot iron to get ride of the bone that had gone bad, and that would elimainate the grading system. In paragraph 1 it states, " For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage. " This quotes explains how the workers of the factory had been trained to use spoiled meat for anything they could. This connects with how the factory uses spoiled meat because they wouldn't let anything go to waste, and would make sure they would make the most money possible. This connects overallwith the idea of hwo the factory was greedy, and focused only on trying to make as much money as possible, not on the safety of their meat products.

There are so many different ways they would cover things up, I've honestly lost count. One technique used is found in Paragraph 2, where the story states that, "In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus,1 by which they saved time and increased the capacity of the plant\u2014a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds." This small section shows that they tried to mask the rotting smell with pickle juice. However, the story goes on to say that failed. Paragraph 4 also shows the true nature of these factories, saying, "There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together. This is no fairy story and no joke; the meat would be shoveled into carts, and the man who did the shoveling would not trouble to lift out a rat even when he saw one \u2013 there were things that went into the sausage in comparison with which a poisoned rat was a tidbit." Just imagine getting all of those germs served on your plate for breakfast. The idea is nauseating. Unsanitary animals would poop on the already dirty meat, only for men to wipe their dirty hands across it. What would be the final product? A rat and poop, poisoned bread, dirty water, filthy hand, rotting meat concoction. This is utterly disgusting and may have just ruined ham for me.

One way the factory would cover up spoiled meat odor was by pickling the hams that were spoiled, and if the meat managed to stink again they would be pickled once more with a stronger solution and sold to the public. In the text it states, "...there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them... the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as \u201cgiving them thirty per cent.\u201d The next way the facotry would use spoiled meat was through dosing moldy and white meat from Europe in borax and glycerin so that it could be served to the public. In the passage it states, "...old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." Then, an invention came about that could allow bad meat to be sold as Grade One meat through inserting a hot white iron in place of the bone. In the passage it states, "...but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron." Lastly, the factory would mix old disgusting meat that had been sitting for months with new meat, borax, and colored gelatin to make it look normal and process it for the public. "Every spring they did it; and in the barrels would be dirt and rust and old nails and stale water \u2013 and cartload after cartload of it would be taken up and dumped into the hoppers with fresh meat... Every spring they did it; and in the barrels would be dirt and rust and old nails and stale water \u2013 and cartload after cartload of it would be taken up and dumped into the hoppers with fresh meat."

There were many ways the factory would use to hinder the condition of the spoiled meat. One of the various ways the factory would cover up spoiled meat was by rubbing the meat against soda to get rid of the odor. According to lines 19-21, "also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." They used the chemistry in the method of rubbing the meat agains the soda to change the appearance and smell of the meat to make it more appetizing however, it hides the true condition of the meat.  Another way the factory covered up the spoiled meat was encorporating glycerin and borax from sausage rejected from Europe-suggesting the conditions of the spoiled meat were noticeable. According to paragraph 3 "it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." Signyfying this was a repeated process to get the sausage accepted to other countries.  Furthermore, the factory would hide the spoiled meat by "giving them thirty-percent" which was done prior to finding hams spoiled from injection.  The text states "Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. This conveys that the factory narrowed down the techniques used to hinder the spoileld condition of the meat first done by intensyfing the amount of pickle to hide the smell to creating devices and apparatuses that extracted the "bad parts" (which created the condition) of the meat, in this case the bone. The new name for the meat being Number One Grade. These are the ways the factory was able to hide the state of the spoiled meat for selling.

There were various ways that factories would use or cover up spoiled meat. The employees played a huge role in why meat was processed under harsh conditions. Workers lacked washing their hands, and the water that men washed their hands in was also ladled into sausages. Meat would be tumbled out on the floor in dust and dirt. Meat would fall onto surfaces where employees have spit thousand of times. As a result of this, meats were extremely treacherous. According to the text, it states, "There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs." The meat was also in a space where rats were present, causing rats to run across the meats. As a result of rats running around, they poison them. After poisoning the rats, the rats would go in the hopper with the meat while they are processing. Workers call the poisoned rat a tidbit, and they did not care to remove the rat from the meat. This was extremely unsanitary and cruel. According to the text, it states, "There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms, and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it." Workers were also capable of changing the meat into; however, they wanted them, such as turning the meat brown or making the meat "unspoil." They would use chemistry and machines to change spoiled meat. If it were so difficult to get these meats to change, they would sell it as a number three grade meat. According to the text, it states, "Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as "Number Three Grade," but later on, some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron." The workers also rubbed meat in soda to get meat to go from sour to sweet and change the bad odor. After doing this, they would provide it to people over the free lunch counter. These conditions were very harsh, but workers did not care about deceiving the public; they only wanted money.

And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor\u2014a process known to the workers as \u201cgiving them thirty per cent.\u201d Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as \u201cNumber Three Grade,\u201d but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade\u2014there was only Number One Grade. The packers were always originating such schemes\u2014they had what they called \u201cboneless hams,\u201d which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and \u201cCalifornia hams,\u201d which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy \u201cskinned hams,\u201d which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no one would buy them\u2014that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled \u201chead cheese!\u201d

In the article, Excerpt From The Jungle, there were many ways factories tried to cover up spoiled meat. Throughout this article it tells us that no matter the color, flavor, or smell they would still sell the meat. These factories didn't care for the health of their consumers and only wanted to make money, so they sold every piece of meat that they could. While reading this article it sounds like they would never let a single piece of meat go to waste even if it was spoiled and covered in mold. In the article it states, \u201cold sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white \u2013 it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption.\u201d(3). This quote from the article explains to us how they covered up the molded meat by using strong and toxic chemicals to get rid of the smell and turn the meat back to brown. The factories had no health regulations, the meat was stored in places infested with germs. The factories knew how filthy their facility was and had put no effort in  to change it. In paragraph 4 it states, \u201cThere would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs.\u201d(4). This tells us how nobody cared about the condition the meat was in and how no one enforced them to follow any guidelines that had been put in place. Workers knew that what they were doing was wrong and never second guessed it, \u201ca man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together.\u201d(4). This quote from the article tells the reader how they used rat meat for sausages. These rats contained many diseases and carried poison from eating contaminated  bread. Which they thought was right to feed  humans. In the factories, spoiled meat was covered up badly. Instead of throwing away the rotting meat they found ways to use it to seem consumable to humanity while they were making it much worse.

The meatpacking houses would disguise the taste, smell, color, and presentation of the meat to cover up the fact that it was spoiled. Sinclair describes the process from the word of a pickle room worker, "... the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. " (Paragraph 2).  He goes on to explain that they still worked with meat that had an unbearable smell to the workers and they would just pickle the meat stronger to destroy the oder. He also added that The meatpacking houses would disguise the taste, smell, color, and presentation of the meat to cover up the fact that it was spoiled. Sinclair describes the process from the word of a pickle room worker, "... the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. " (Paragraph 2).  He goes on to explain that they still worked with meat that had an unbearable smell and they would just pickle the meat stronger to destroy the oder. He also added that that some spoiled meat that contained white coloring and mold would be used for sausages and home consumption.  Sinclair starts to  explain the sausage process, "Some of it they would make into "smoked" sausage \u2013 but as the smoking took time, and was therefore expensive, they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown. " (Paragraph 5).  He proceeds to state that all the sausages were the same but some were labled differently to uncrease the price.  He also adds that no one pays attention to what goes in the sausage as long as its made. The meatpacking houses wrongfly hid the condition of the meat by altering the taste with stronger pickling, smell by scrubbing it with soda, color by using different chemicals that were unhealthy, and presentation by either grinding it, choping it, or whatever else was acceptable.

The ways that the meatpacking  factory would cover up spoiled mean was doing things such as injecting chemicals into it and even taking every bit of the left over spoiledd meat and blending it up to put it inot sausage. In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus,[BR] by which they saved time and increased the capacity[BR] of the plant\u2014a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. In the novle "the jungle" by Upton Sinclair he describes how the meat packing industery worked with the meat. He went on to describe in detail the horriable unsafe, disgusting, and moraliy wrong prosses that of which the meat was packaged. One thing the industery would do is putting many chemicals into the rotten meat to make it look better so that people would buy it.  As seen in the novel, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell [...] also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus, by which they saved time and increased the capacity of the plant\u2014a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. [...]  Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as \u201cNumber Three Grade,\u201d but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron."(Sinclair 2). This qoute shows how the industery would use jsut about any means to sell the meat they had even if it ment using unsafe means to change it completly. Such as droping loads of rotten meat into tubs of vinager and leaving it so that it would be more appealing.  In "The Jungle" it also states, "Some of it they would make into "smoked" sausage \u2013 but as the smoking took time, and was therefore expensive, they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown." (Sinclair 5). This qoute shows one of the many dangerous chemicals they would put in the meat, as borax is a cleaning tool. Eatting could lead to death as seen in www.medicalnewstoday.com it states, "Borax is not safe to ingest. According to the NLM's Toxicology Data Network, borax is easy for the body to break down when either inhaled or swallowed. However, if inhalation or ingestion occurs, both serious poisoning and organ damage can result."(Wilson 2019). This quote shows how dangerous it is to ingest Borax.

The first way the factory would cover up spoiled meat was to put it in sausage. In paragraph one the author writes, "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever mear was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage." This explains how they would put spoiled meat with fresh meat, instead of throwing the spoiled meat out. If the factory didn't put the spoiled meat in sausage, they would rub it with soda to take away the small, or they would use chemicals to enhance aspects of the meat. From paragraph two it states, "...how the meat that was taken our of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." This explains there use of soda and chemicals to mask the spoiled meat. Next up, the factory would stuff ham with the spoiled meat using a machine and a needle. The text explains in paragraph two, "... a cachine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled..." This evidence further describes how they would mask spoiled meat. Finally, once the factory discovered how to take the bone out of a ham, they would insert a white-hot iron, and they would go on to sell "boneless hams" or "California hams" and fancy "skinned hams" which all were filled with spoiled meat. However no one would buy skinned hams, until they were cooked, and chopped up fine, which they then called "head cheese". Evidence comes from paragraph two, "...but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. The packers were always originating such schemes\u2014they had what they called \u201cboneless hams,\u201d which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and \u201cCalifornia hams,\u201d which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy \u201cskinned hams,\u201d which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no one would buy them\u2014that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled \u201chead cheese!\u201d These lines of text explain the procedure that happened to the hams just for them to be sold. If Europe old sausage came back however, no matter how moldy or white it was, the factoru would dose it with borax and glycerin and then pack it with fresh meat just to sell again.

The experiment took place at Cubberley High School in Palo Alto, California, during the first week of April 1967. Jones, finding himself unable to explain to his students how the German population could have claimed ignorance of The Holocaust, decided to demonstrate it to them instead.  Jones started a movement called <<The Third Wave>> and told his students that the movement aimed to eliminate democracy.  Jones himself wrote a detailed account of the experiment some nine years afterward and more articles about the experiment followed, including some interviews with Jones and the original students.

The Third Wave experiment took place at Cubberley High School in Palo Alto, California during the first week of April 1967. History teacher Ron Jones, finding himself unable to explain to his students how people throughout history followed the crowd even when terrible things were happening, decided to demonstrate it to his students through an experiment. Jones announced that he was starting a movement aimed to eliminate democracy. Jones named the movement \u201cThe Third Wave\u201d as a symbol of strength, referring to the mythical belief that the third in a series of waves is the strongest.

The Third Wave experiment took place at Cubberley High School in Palo Alto, California during the first week of April 1967. Jones started the first day of the experiment emphasizing simple things like proper seating, and drilled the students extensively until they got it right. After only three days, the experiment took on a life of its own, with students from all over the school joining in. By the fourth day of the experiment, the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control. At the end of the week, instead of a televised address of their leader, the students were presented with a blank channel.

Also this experiment made students believe they were apart of something important . Members began to discriminate against the students that had not joined. Members also began reporting to Mr. Jones if they thought another member was going aganist the rules, and the members assaigned themselves jobs that would help further the movement. Overall the experiment was ended because it got out of hand and Mr. Jones believed that the student's didipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that it was slipping out of control.

History teacher Ron Jones, created the Third Wave experiment in order to demonstrate how people throughout history followed the crowd despite terrible things occurring. The Third Wave developed over such a short period of time because Jones was enforcing rules that gave the students a "supreme sense of discipline and community" (paragraph 2). Such rules included proper seating, classroom discipline, and saluting each other outside of the classroom. By implementing these rules, he became an authoritarian figure to whom his students became loyal. Soon, other students began joining and were being initiate based on what Mr. Jones was telling his students. This quick escalation caused Jones to end the experiment because he believed that it was getting out of control.

The third wave was an experiment developed by Ron Jones, a high school teacher at Cubberley High School in Palo Alto, California in 1969. The experiment was a demonstration of how democratic states are not usually protected by the influence of fascism which is the belief in absolute control of all people by a single dictator.  Ron developed an authoritative dictatorship in the classroom to teach students the German mentality. He established rules such as students should stand up when asking or answering questions in three words, students saluting each other similar to that of the Nazi at school and even outside of school. On the fourth day, Ron ended the experiment when he realized that it was slipping out of his control. The students had become extremely involved in the project with high discipline and loyalty to the project.
